claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadens the displayed antigen repertoire on tumor cells.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3%
Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination

claims.caveat: This finding is from mouse models, and the broadening of the antigen repertoire does not guarantee a therapeutic effect.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination in the tumor enhances the presentation of peptides on MHC-I.

evidence.quote: Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6%

claims.caveat: This was observed in murine models and may not directly translate to human tumors.

claims.claim: Prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination is associated with improved survival in human patients treated with ICI.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01
Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is a significant threat to validity.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination induces a strong type I interferon response, which is critical for the sensitization effect.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: This mechanistic link was established in mouse models and requires further validation in humans.
